{
  "article_text": [
    "the purpose of this paper is to demonstrate that simplicial trees have the potential to be used as an effective tool in resolutions of monomial ideals .",
    "as first noted by diane taylor  @xcite , given an ideal @xmath0 in a polynomial ring @xmath1 minimally generated by monomials @xmath2 , a free resolution of @xmath0 can be given by the simplicial chain complex of a simplex with @xmath3 vertices .",
    "most often taylor s resolution is not minimal .",
    "bayer , peeva and sturmfels  @xcite refined taylor",
    "s construction : they provided a criterion to check if the simplicial chain complex of any simplicial complex on @xmath3 vertices is a ( minimal ) free resolution of @xmath0 ( theorem  [ t : bps ] ) .",
    "if @xmath4 is a simplicial complex with @xmath3 vertices , the criterion of bayer , peeva and sturmfels determines if @xmath4 supports a free resolution of @xmath0 based on whether certain subcomplexes of @xmath4 are acyclic .",
    "the goal of this note is to point out that if the simplicial complex @xmath4 being considered is a simplicial tree  ( definition  [ d : tree ] ) , then all that needs to be checked is that these subcomplexes are connected .",
    "we accomplish this by proving that simplicial trees are acyclic  ( theorem  [ t : collapsible ] ) , and every induced subcomplex of a simplicial tree is a simplicial forest  ( theorem  [ t : induced ] ) .",
    "we then use a result of peeva and velasco  @xcite to conclude that every simplicial tree supports a minimal resolution of a monomial ideal .",
    "peeva and velasco s result is that every simplicial complex ( other than the boundary of a simplex ) is the scarf complex of some monomial ideal , and they give a specific method to build such an ideal .",
    "we refine their result to describe ideals minimally resolved by a scarf complex , and therefore by a given simplicial tree .",
    "a _ simplicial complex _ @xmath4 over a set of vertices @xmath5 is a collection of subsets of @xmath6 , with the property that @xmath7 for all @xmath8 , and if @xmath9 then all subsets of @xmath10 are also in @xmath4 .",
    "an element of @xmath4 is called a _ face _ of @xmath4 , and the _ dimension _ of a face @xmath10 of @xmath4 is defined as @xmath11 , where @xmath12 is the number of vertices of @xmath10 .",
    "the faces of dimensions 0 and 1 are called _ vertices _ and _ edges _ , respectively , and @xmath13",
    ". the maximal faces of @xmath4 under inclusion are called _ facets _ of @xmath4 .",
    "the dimension of the simplicial complex @xmath4 is the maximal dimension of its facets .",
    "a subcollection of @xmath4 is a simplicial complex whose facets are also facets of @xmath4 ; in other words a simplicial complex generated by a subset of the set of facets of @xmath4 .",
    "suppose @xmath4 is a simplicial complex with facets @xmath14 .",
    "the simplicial complex obtained by _ removing the facet _",
    "@xmath15 from @xmath4 is the simplicial complex @xmath16    a facet @xmath10 of a simplicial complex is called a _ leaf _ if either @xmath10 is the only facet of @xmath4 , or for some facet @xmath17 we have @xmath18 equivalently , a facet @xmath10 is a leaf of @xmath4 if @xmath19 is a face of @xmath20 .",
    "note that it follows immediately from the definition above that a leaf @xmath10 must contain at least one _ free vertex _ ; namely a vertex that belongs to no other facet of @xmath4 but @xmath10 .    [",
    "d : tree ] a connected simplicial complex @xmath4 is a _ tree _ if every nonempty subcollection of @xmath4 has a leaf .",
    "if @xmath4 is not necessarily connected , but every subcollection has a leaf , then @xmath4 is called a _",
    "forest_.    [ d : induced ] suppose @xmath4 is a simplicial complex over a vertex set @xmath6 and let @xmath21 .",
    "the _ induced subcomplex on @xmath22 _ , denoted by @xmath23 , is defined as @xmath24    [ t : induced ] an induced subcomplex of a simplicial tree is a simplicial forest .",
    "let @xmath25 be a simplicial tree and suppose @xmath26 is a subset of the vertex set of @xmath4 .",
    "we would like to show that @xmath23 is a forest .",
    "the facets of @xmath23 are clearly a subset of @xmath27 .",
    "let @xmath28 be a subcollection of @xmath23 consisting of facets @xmath29 .",
    "we need to show @xmath28 has a leaf .",
    "since @xmath4 is a tree , the corresponding subcollection @xmath30 of @xmath4 has a leaf @xmath31 with joint @xmath32 .",
    "so for every @xmath33 we have @xmath34 which implies that @xmath35 so @xmath36 is a leaf of @xmath28 and therefore @xmath23 is a forest .",
    "one property of simplicial trees that we will need is that they are acyclic .",
    "while this can be shown via a direct calculation of homological cycles and boundaries , we show more : simplicial trees are collapsible , hence contractible , and therefore acyclic .",
    "we refer the reader to  @xcite for more details on these concepts .",
    "[ d : collapsible ] let @xmath4 be a simplicial complex and @xmath37 be a maximal proper face of exactly one facet @xmath10 of @xmath4 .",
    "the complex @xmath38 is said to be obtained from @xmath4 using an _",
    "elementary collapse_. if a sequence of elementary collapses reduces @xmath4 to a single point , then @xmath4 is called _",
    "below we use the phrase `` @xmath4 collapses to @xmath39 '' to imply that the complex @xmath39 can be obtained from @xmath4 via a sequence of elementary collapses .",
    "[ p : simplex ] let @xmath4 be a simplex with facet @xmath10 and let @xmath37 be a proper nonempty face of @xmath10 .",
    "then @xmath4 collapses to @xmath40 .",
    "in particular , every simplex is collapsible .",
    "suppose @xmath41 .",
    "we use induction on @xmath42 .",
    "the case @xmath43 is clear , since @xmath37 would be a point , say @xmath44 , and the edge @xmath45 clearly collapses to @xmath44 .",
    "suppose @xmath46 and let @xmath47 be the maximal proper faces of @xmath10 where for each @xmath8 , @xmath48 .",
    "suppose , without loss of generality , @xmath49 .",
    "we perform the following elementary collapse on @xmath4 : @xmath50    [ c : simplex ] for @xmath51 there is a series of elementary collapses taking the complex @xmath52 to the complex @xmath53 .    if @xmath54 , then the complex @xmath55 has @xmath56 as a maximal proper face of @xmath57 ( note that @xmath58 if @xmath59 ) .",
    "now we do the elementary collapse @xmath60 and we are done .    now suppose that we have arrived at @xmath61 . in",
    "what follows we will repeatedly use two basic observations .    1",
    ".   the maximal proper subfaces of a face @xmath62 are of the form @xmath63 2 .",
    "suppose @xmath64 and @xmath65",
    ". then we have @xmath66    so the maximal proper faces of @xmath15 that are not contained in any of @xmath67 are @xmath68 let @xmath69 . using  ( 1 ) and",
    "( 2 ) above we perform the repeated elementary collapses @xmath70    it now follows from repeated applications of claim  [ c : simplex ] that @xmath4 collapses to @xmath71 , which is a simplex on @xmath72 vertices . if @xmath73 , we are done , and if not the induction hypothesis implies that @xmath74 collapses to @xmath75 via a series of elementary collapses .",
    "[ t : collapsible ] simplicial trees are collapsible , and therefore contractible and acyclic .",
    "we prove this by induction on the number @xmath3 of facets of a simplicial tree @xmath4 .",
    "if @xmath76 the statement follows from proposition  [ p : simplex ] .",
    "suppose @xmath77 and let @xmath10 be a leaf of @xmath4 with joint @xmath78 .",
    "let @xmath79 .",
    "we know by proposition  [ p : simplex ] that @xmath80 reduces to @xmath40 via a series of elementary collapses",
    ". moreover , the faces being eliminated in in each of the collapses are not faces of @xmath20 , since they are not faces of @xmath81 .",
    "therefore , all the elementary collapses that reduce @xmath82 to @xmath40 are elementary collapses on @xmath4 that reduce @xmath4 to @xmath20 .",
    "the latter is a tree with @xmath83 facets , and hence collapsible by the induction hypothesis .",
    "all collapsible complexes are contractible so the rest of the statement follows directly .",
    "we now review monomial resolutions as described by bayer , peeva and sturmfels  @xcite and show how simplicial trees fit in that picture .",
    "the construction in  @xcite considers a monomial ideal @xmath0 in a polynomial ring @xmath84 over a field , where @xmath0 is minimally generated by monomials @xmath85 .",
    "if @xmath4 is a simplicial complex on @xmath86 vertices , once can label each vertex of @xmath4 with one of the generators of @xmath85 and each face with the least common multiple of the labels of its vertices .",
    "if @xmath87 is a monomial in @xmath84 , let @xmath88 be the subcomplex of @xmath4 induced on the vertices of @xmath4 whose labels divide @xmath87 .",
    "[ t : bps ] let @xmath4 be a simplicial complex labeled by monomials @xmath89 , and let @xmath90 be the ideal in @xmath84 generated by the vertex labels .",
    "the chain complex @xmath91 of @xmath4 is a free resolution of @xmath92 if and only if the induced subcomplex @xmath88 is empty or acyclic for every monomial @xmath93 .",
    "moreover , @xmath94 is a minimal free resolution if and only if @xmath95 for every proper subface @xmath96 of a face @xmath97 .",
    "note that we can determine whether @xmath94 is a resolution just by checking the vanishing condition for monomials that are least common multiples of sets of vertex labels .",
    "combinatorially what theorem  [ t : bps ] is saying that the betti vector of @xmath92 is bounded by the @xmath98-vector of an eligible @xmath4 : @xmath99 with equality holding if some extra conditions are satisfied .",
    "we now turn our attention back to simplicial trees .",
    "if the @xmath4 under consideration in theorem  [ t : bps ] is a tree , then we can show the following .",
    "[ t : main ] let @xmath4 be a simplicial tree labeled by monomials @xmath100 , and let @xmath90 be the ideal in @xmath84 generated by the vertex labels .",
    "the chain complex @xmath101 is a free resolution of @xmath92 if and only if the induced subcomplex @xmath88 is connected for every monomial @xmath87 .    by theorem  [ t : induced ]",
    "every induced subcomplex of @xmath4 is a forest . by theorem  [ t : collapsible ] forests",
    "are acyclic in all but possibly the @xmath102-th reduced homology , that is they may not be connected .",
    "this proves the theorem .",
    "the strength of theorem  [ t : main ] is in that it reduces the question of whether a simplicial complex resolves an ideal to checking whether some of its induced subcomplexes are connected .",
    "one type of question one could then ask is given a tree @xmath4 , what ideals could it resolve ?",
    "our first example displays this line of questioning .",
    "[ e : gen ] let @xmath4 be the simplicial tree below on @xmath103 vertices , which we have labeled with monomials @xmath104 .",
    "@xmath105{ex5.eps}\\ ] ]    the only induced subcomplex of @xmath4 that is not connected is the one induced on the vertices labeled @xmath106 and @xmath107 , so by theorem  [ t : main ] for @xmath108 to be resolved by @xmath4 we need to have @xmath109    a more concrete example using the same complex comes next .",
    "[ e : scarf ] the ideal @xmath110 can be resolved by @xmath4 .",
    "@xmath111{concrete-2.eps}\\ ] ] however @xmath112",
    "so the resolution is not minimal .",
    "we try to make it minimal by removing the faces with equal labels . @xmath111{concrete-3.eps}\\ ] ] note that the resulting complex is also a simplicial tree satisfying the conditions of theorem  [ t : main ] and whose @xmath98-vector is @xmath113 .",
    "it therefore minimally resolves @xmath92 .",
    "we now come to the question of which monomial ideals can be ( minimally ) resolved by a simplicial tree .",
    "it is known from work of velasco  @xcite that there are classes of monomial ideals whose resolutions are not supported by any simplicial complex . however , most simplicial complexes , and all simplicial trees do appear as _ scarf complexes _ of some monomial ideal .",
    "given a monomial ideal its scarf complex is a subcomplex of its taylor complex with the same labeling and with the added condition that if a face has the same label as another face , neither face can appear in the scarf complex . the last simplicial complex appearing in example  [ e : scarf ] is a scarf complex of the ideal @xmath0 in that example .        1 .",
    "@xmath4 is the scarf complex of a monomial ideal if and only if @xmath4 is not the boundary of a simplex on @xmath114 vertices .",
    "@xmath4 minimally resolves a monomial ideal if and only if @xmath4 is acyclic .",
    "an ideal ( minimally ) resolved by its scarf complex is called a _",
    "scarf ideal_. given an eligible simplicial complex @xmath4 with vertices labeled @xmath115 , peeva and velasco in  @xcite build a scarf ideal @xmath116 using the following steps .",
    "define a variable @xmath117 corresponding to each face @xmath118 of @xmath4 . in the polynomial ring generated by all these variables , define the ideal @xmath116 whose generators are enumerated by the vertices of @xmath4 , and for every given vertex @xmath119 of @xmath4 , the corresponding monomial generator is the product of all @xmath117 where @xmath120 . in short @xmath121    the ideal @xmath116 defined above",
    "is generated by rather large monomials . in what follows",
    "we will demonstrate that one can shave off some variables in each monomial to reduce the size of the generator and still have a scarf ideal of @xmath4 .",
    "suppose @xmath4 is a simplicial complex with vertices labeled @xmath115 . and for each vertex @xmath119 let @xmath122 be the set of facets of @xmath4 that do not contain @xmath119 , and let @xmath123 be the set of facets of @xmath4 that do contain @xmath119",
    ". with variables labeled as described above , define the ideal @xmath124 where @xmath125            clearly @xmath130 .",
    "if @xmath131 , then @xmath132 can only be a maximal proper face of a facet in @xmath133 ; otherwise @xmath134 and @xmath135 , therefore @xmath136 which is a contradiction since @xmath137 .",
    "in particular @xmath138 .",
    "so we can label the vertices of @xmath4 with the monomials @xmath141 , where the labeling is consistent with @xmath142 as in ( [ e : j ] ) .",
    "next we have to make sure that @xmath4 is a scarf complex of @xmath127 . for this purpose and",
    "what follows , the next claim will be useful .      for ease of argument",
    "we label the above @xmath147s from the left to right with the symbols @xmath148 , @xmath149 , @xmath150 and @xmath151 , respectively .",
    "now suppose @xmath152 .",

    "conversely , suppose @xmath153 .",
    "then , in particular , we have @xmath154 so all the factors @xmath155 where @xmath10 is a facet of @xmath4 are the same in both monomials @xmath148 and @xmath149 , as well as all @xmath117 for maximal proper faces @xmath118 of such @xmath10 .",
    "so we only have to worry about terms of the form @xmath156 for a facet @xmath78 of @xmath4 that contains @xmath140 .",
    "suppose @xmath157 .",
    "if @xmath158 appears in @xmath148 , we are done , as @xmath159 is a maximal proper face of @xmath78 which appears as a label in @xmath149 as well . if not , we conclude that @xmath160 , which means that @xmath118 and @xmath161 are both faces of @xmath4 with the same @xmath147s ; a contradiction as @xmath4 is a scarf complex of @xmath116 .",
    "we now show that if @xmath4 is acyclic , then it supports a ( minimal ) resolution of @xmath127 .",
    "so we need to show that for any set of vertices @xmath162 of @xmath4 , the induced subcomplex on the vertex set @xmath163 is acyclic .",
    "notice that @xmath164 which by claim  [ c : scarf ] is equivalent to @xmath165 so the induced subcomplex @xmath23 is the same under both labelings ( by @xmath116 and @xmath127 ) , and is therefore acyclic",
    ".        computational evidence has shown that many ideals `` in - between '' @xmath116 and @xmath127 can be resolved by @xmath4 , though not all of them , as indicated in example  [ e : montreal ] . given a vertex @xmath119 of @xmath4 , we know that @xmath171 where by @xmath172 we are denoting the product of the @xmath117 that do not appear in @xmath173 .",
    "[ p : scarf ] let @xmath4 be a simplicial complex on @xmath42 vertices which is not the boundary of a simplex . for a vertex @xmath119 of @xmath4 ,",
    "let the monomials @xmath174 , @xmath175 and @xmath176 be as defined in ( [ e : j ] ) , ( [ e : j ] ) and ( [ e : j  ] ) , respectively , and suppose @xmath177 is a monomial such that @xmath178 .",
    "let @xmath0 be the monomial ideal @xmath179 then the scarf complex @xmath28 of @xmath0 has @xmath42 vertices and contains @xmath4 as a subcomplex .",
    "first we have to show that @xmath0 has no redundant generators .",
    "consider two monomials @xmath180 and @xmath181 for some @xmath129 .",
    "we have proved before that @xmath182 , so there there are two possibilities :    1 .",
    "there is @xmath183 such that @xmath184 ( therefore @xmath185 ) , in which case @xmath186 , and therefore @xmath187 ; a contradiction .",
    "2 .   @xmath188 , in which case there is @xmath189 such @xmath190 , so @xmath191 and therefore @xmath192 which implies that @xmath193 so @xmath194 , and therefore @xmath187 .",
    "let @xmath28 be the scarf complex of @xmath0 and suppose @xmath143 and @xmath144 are two faces of the simplex on @xmath145 with the same labels : @xmath196 suppose @xmath197 for some @xmath8 , then we have @xmath198 .",
    "so all variables labeled by facets in @xmath199 , their maximal proper faces , and by @xmath200 for @xmath201 already appear in @xmath202 .",
    "therefore @xmath203 since @xmath4 is the scarf complex for @xmath116 , this implies that @xmath204 .",
    "similarly we have @xmath205 .",
    "this proves that the scarf complex @xmath28 of @xmath0 contains @xmath4 .",
    "[ e : montreal ] for the complex @xmath4 below @xmath206{montreal - examp.eps}\\ ] ] we have @xmath207 and @xmath208 where @xmath209 in this case , @xmath210 as expected ( though @xmath116 and @xmath127 have different graded betti numbers ) .",
    "it is worth noting that only very low degree choices of @xmath177 will give strictly larger scarf complexes .",
    "that is , given an acyclic simplicial complex , one can find a whole class of scarf ideals for it by making appropriate ( large enough ) choices for the monomials @xmath177 .",
    "there are many questions that naturally follow from this work , answers to which would greatly contribute to understanding monomial resolutions .",
    "for example , can one describe classes of monomial ideals resolved by a given tree ?",
    "what roles do localization , removal of facets and other such operations that preserve forests play on scarf ideals ?",
    "can one describe classes of complexes ( trees ) resolving a given monomial ideal ?"
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we explore resolutions of monomial ideals supported by simplicial trees . </S>",
    "<S> we argue that since simplicial trees are acyclic , the criterion of bayer , peeva and sturmfels for checking if a simplicial complex supports a free resolution of a monomial ideal reduces to checking that certain induced subcomplexes are connected . </S>",
    "<S> we then use results of peeva and velasco to show that every simplicial tree appears as the scarf complex of a monomial ideal , and hence supports a minimal resolution . </S>",
    "<S> we also provide a way to construct smaller scarf ideals than those constructed by peeva and velasco . </S>"
  ]
}
